Scheme 1

The ligands used in the construction of MOFs.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0020" view="all">Two new three-dimensional (3D) porous metal-organic frameworks, [Ni(tpt)<ce:inf loc="post">2/3</ce:inf>(bpta)<ce:inf loc="post">1/4</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(OH)]⋅solve (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and [Cd(tpt)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>bpta)]⋅solve (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) (tpt<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>2,4,6-tris(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine, H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>bpta<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>(1,1'-biphenyl)-2,2',6,6'-tetracarboxylic acid) have been prepared, and characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, IR spectra, PXRD, and TG analysis. The results show that complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> has a 3D bor network structure with 56.9% solvent-accessible volume, and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> reveals a novol 3,5-coordinated chiral topology with vertex symbol (4.7<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>)(4<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.7<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>.8) and 52.5% accessible void in the structure. Moreover, gas adsorption properties of desolvated <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were investigated.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract
Two new three-dimensional (3D) porous metal-organic frameworks, [Ni(tpt)2/3(bpta)1/4(H2O)2(OH)]⋅solve (1) and [Cd(tpt)(H2bpta)]⋅solve (2) (tpt=2,4,6-tris(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine, H4bpta=(1,1'-biphenyl)-2,2',6,6'-tetracarboxylic acid) have been prepared, and characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, IR spectra, PXRD, and TG analysis. The results show that complex 1 has a 3D bor network structure with 56.9% solvent-accessible volume, and 2 reveals a novol 3,5-coordinated chiral topology with vertex symbol (4.72)(43.62.74.8) and 52.5% accessible void in the structure. Moreover, gas adsorption properties of desolvated 1 and 2 were investigated.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0025" view="all">Two new three-dimensional (3D) porous metal-organic frameworks, [Ni(tpt)<ce:inf loc="post">2/3</ce:inf>(bpta)<ce:inf loc="post">1/4</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(OH)]⋅solve (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and [Cd(tpt)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>bpta)]⋅solve (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) (tpt<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>2,4,6-tris(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine, H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>bpta<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>(1,1'-biphenyl)-2,2',6,6'-tetracarboxylic acid) have been prepared, and characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, IR spectra, PXRD, and TG analysis. The resulted MOFs reveal highly accessible voids. Moreover, gas adsorption properties of desolvated <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were investigated.<ce:display>

elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract
Two new three-dimensional (3D) porous metal-organic frameworks, [Ni(tpt)2/3(bpta)1/4(H2O)2(OH)]⋅solve (1) and [Cd(tpt)(H2bpta)]⋅solve (2) (tpt=2,4,6-tris(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine, H4bpta=(1,1'-biphenyl)-2,2',6,6'-tetracarboxylic acid) have been prepared, and characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, IR spectra, PXRD, and TG analysis. The resulted MOFs reveal highly accessible voids. Moreover, gas adsorption properties of desolvated 1 and 2 were investigated.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0020">
<ce:link locator="fx1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>

<ce:section-title>Research Highlights</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0030" view="all">► Two porous MOFs with new topologies have been synthesized. ► The resulted MOFs reveal highly accessible voids. ► The gas adsorption properties of the reported MOFs have been investigated.</ce:simple-para><ce:para id="p0005" view="all">Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted a great deal of attention in the past decade because of their captivating structural diversities and intriguing potential applications, such as gas storage and separation, catalysis, drug delivery, and chemical sensing . MOFs are generally constructed by discrete metal polyhedra or isolated small clusters coordinated to linking organic functional groups which have been widely used in the construction of metal–organic complexes with various dimensional networks and interesting properties .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Research Highlights
► Two porous MOFs with new topologies have been synthesized. ► The resulted MOFs reveal highly accessible voids. ► The gas adsorption properties of the reported MOFs have been investigated.
Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted a great deal of attention in the past decade because of their captivating structural diversities and intriguing potential applications, such as gas storage and separation, catalysis, drug delivery, and chemical sensing . MOFs are generally constructed by discrete metal polyhedra or isolated small clusters coordinated to linking organic functional groups which have been widely used in the construction of metal–organic complexes with various dimensional networks and interesting properties .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0010" view="all">Among the multidentate pyridine ligands investigated in this field, 2,4,6-tris(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine (tpt) is of specially interest in recent years. Its rigidity and triangular geometry can lead to MOFs bearing various structures and interesting topologies when employed in the reactions with metal ions  and the resulted compounds also show attractive properties such as host-guest functions, magnetic and drug delivery . However, in despite of the high solvent-accessible volume of the resulting frameworks or cages, none of the tpt constructed porous frameworks have been studied with their gas adsorption properties to the best of our knowledge. As the combination of tpt and carboxylic acid ligand resulted in MOFs with novel structures and interesting properties , our goal is to design and synthesize porous MOFs with tpt and various carboxylic acid ligands. Herein, we report two novel microporous metal–organic frameworks constructed by Ni(II)/Cd(II) and tpt associated with (1,1'-biphenyl)-2,2',6,6'-tetracarboxylic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>bpta) (
<ce:float-anchor refid="sch0005"></ce:float-anchor>). The resulted MOFs were characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, IR spectra, PXRD, and TG analysis. Also, the resulted MOFs reveal high solvent-accessible volume and novel topologies. Furthermore, their gas adsorption properties were investigated.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Among the multidentate pyridine ligands investigated in this field, 2,4,6-tris(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine (tpt) is of specially interest in recent years. Its rigidity and triangular geometry can lead to MOFs bearing various structures and interesting topologies when employed in the reactions with metal ions  and the resulted compounds also show attractive properties such as host-guest functions, magnetic and drug delivery . However, in despite of the high solvent-accessible volume of the resulting frameworks or cages, none of the tpt constructed porous frameworks have been studied with their gas adsorption properties to the best of our knowledge. As the combination of tpt and carboxylic acid ligand resulted in MOFs with novel structures and interesting properties , our goal is to design and synthesize porous MOFs with tpt and various carboxylic acid ligands. Herein, we report two novel microporous metal–organic frameworks constructed by Ni(II)/Cd(II) and tpt associated with (1,1'-biphenyl)-2,2',6,6'-tetracarboxylic acid (H4bpta) (
). The resulted MOFs were characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, IR spectra, PXRD, and TG analysis. Also, the resulted MOFs reveal high solvent-accessible volume and novel topologies. Furthermore, their gas adsorption properties were investigated.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0015" view="all">Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, [Ni(tpt)<ce:inf loc="post">2/3</ce:inf>(bpta)<ce:inf loc="post">1/4</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(OH)]⋅solve (solve represent for the unidentifiable solvent molecules), was obtained by the reaction of H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>bpta with tpt and Ni(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>⋅<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O in hydrothermal condition  and characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction . Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> crystallizes in the <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>-43<ce:italic>c</ce:italic> space group. In <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, tpt ligands and metal ions assembled into eight interpenetrating (10,3)-a networks which has been observed in Zn(tpt)<ce:inf loc="post">2/3</ce:inf>(SiF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(MeOH) as reported by B.F. Abrahams et al. . However, the coordinated SiF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2-</ce:sup> anion in the reported architecture was replaced with one dehydrogenized carboxyl from H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>bpta, and the coordination sphere of the six coordinated Ni(II) center was accomplished with two water molecules and one hydroxyl group. The Ni–O bond lengths vary from 2.049(3) to 2.088(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>Å, and the Ni–N bond lengths range from 2.093(2) to 2.108(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>Å. Benefiting from its structure characteristic, each bpa<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> joint two left- and two right-handed individual chiral (10,3)-a subnets together by coordinating to Ni(II) ions from the corresponding subnets. As the individual (10,3)-a subnets interconnected by bpa<ce:sup loc="post">4-</ce:sup> ligands, a complicated three dimensional porous framework was achieved. In the structural view, the discrete networks were banded together and the eight interpenetrating (10,3)-a topology was modified by the connectivity increased from the presenting of bpa<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> ligands. To simplify and realize the structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, bpa<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> ligand could be viewed as four connected vertex and the stacking tpt ligands could be viewed as triangle building blocks (a<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>), then the overall structure could be simplified into a network bearing <ce:bold>bor</ce:bold> topology (b). According to the topology of the framework, the free volume found in the framework of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> could be divided into chambers and channels, separately. In the octahedron double-wall chambers raised from the connection of four triangle building blocks and six vertexes, the dimension between the opposite vertexes is about 21.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and the triangle window formed has 10.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å length edge, slightly bigger than the similar reported coordination cage . The channels formed among the stacking vertex shared chambers has a diameter about 9.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The solvent-accessible volume of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> calculated using the PLATON  was 56.9% (44,468.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> out of the 78,200.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> unit cell volume). This value is comparable to that found in some of the most open zeolites, such as faujasite in which the free space is 45-50% of the crystal volume.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Compound 1, [Ni(tpt)2/3(bpta)1/4(H2O)2(OH)]⋅solve (solve represent for the unidentifiable solvent molecules), was obtained by the reaction of H4bpta with tpt and Ni(NO3)2
⋅6H2O in hydrothermal condition  and characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction . Compound 1 crystallizes in the F-43c space group. In 1, tpt ligands and metal ions assembled into eight interpenetrating (10,3)-a networks which has been observed in Zn(tpt)2/3(SiF6)(H2O)2(MeOH) as reported by B.F. Abrahams et al. . However, the coordinated SiF6
2- anion in the reported architecture was replaced with one dehydrogenized carboxyl from H4bpta, and the coordination sphere of the six coordinated Ni(II) center was accomplished with two water molecules and one hydroxyl group. The Ni–O bond lengths vary from 2.049(3) to 2.088(3)Å, and the Ni–N bond lengths range from 2.093(2) to 2.108(3)Å. Benefiting from its structure characteristic, each bpa4− joint two left- and two right-handed individual chiral (10,3)-a subnets together by coordinating to Ni(II) ions from the corresponding subnets. As the individual (10,3)-a subnets interconnected by bpa4- ligands, a complicated three dimensional porous framework was achieved. In the structural view, the discrete networks were banded together and the eight interpenetrating (10,3)-a topology was modified by the connectivity increased from the presenting of bpa4− ligands. To simplify and realize the structure of 1, bpa4− ligand could be viewed as four connected vertex and the stacking tpt ligands could be viewed as triangle building blocks (a), then the overall structure could be simplified into a network bearing bor topology (b). According to the topology of the framework, the free volume found in the framework of 1 could be divided into chambers and channels, separately. In the octahedron double-wall chambers raised from the connection of four triangle building blocks and six vertexes, the dimension between the opposite vertexes is about 21.3Å and the triangle window formed has 10.2Å length edge, slightly bigger than the similar reported coordination cage . The channels formed among the stacking vertex shared chambers has a diameter about 9.5Å. The solvent-accessible volume of 1 calculated using the PLATON  was 56.9% (44,468.4Å3 out of the 78,200.0Å3 unit cell volume). This value is comparable to that found in some of the most open zeolites, such as faujasite in which the free space is 45-50% of the crystal volume.

other properties: Ni–O bond lengths vary from 2.049(3) to 2.088(3)Å
Ni–N bond lengths range from 2.093(2) to 2.108(3)Å
solvent-accessible volume of 1 calculated using the PLATON was 56.9% (44,468.4Å3 out of the 78,200.0Å3 unit cell volume)

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0020" view="all">Compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, [Cd(tpt)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>bpta)]⋅solve, was obtained by the solvothermal reaction of tpt, H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>bpta and Cd(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>⋅<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O in DMF and characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction . In <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the Cd(II) ions are seven coordinated by three nitrogen atoms from three tpt ligands, and four oxygen atoms from two carboxylate groups of two different H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>bpta<ce:sup loc="post">2-</ce:sup> ligands with chelating mode. The Cd–O bond lengths vary from 2.365(17) to 2.422(10)<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>Å, and the Cd–N bond lengths range from 2.393(9) to 2.462(15)<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>Å. Ignoring the connectivity of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>bpta<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup>, the subnet formed by Cd(II) ions and tpt ligands shows 3-coordinated uniform self-penetrating <ce:bold>twt</ce:bold> network topology . However, with the Cd(II) ions interconnected by H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>bpta<ce:sup loc="post">2–</ce:sup>, the whorl of separated helix chains assembled with Cd(II) ions and tpt ligands was supported and reinforced by the coordination of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>bpta<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> with Cd(II) (a<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>) to form a single triple-helix chain. The topology of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> can be explained as follows. The Cd(II) ions could be simplified as five connected nodes meanwhile the tpt ligands can be considered as three connected nodes. As a result, the original <ce:bold>twt</ce:bold> topology was modified into a non-reported 3,5-coordinated chiral topology (c) with vertex symbol (4.7<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>)(4<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.7<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>.8) . A void space analysis indicates that the solvent accessible void in the structure of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> reaches 52.5% (2070.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> out of the 3946.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> unit cell volume).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Compound 2, [Cd(tpt)(H2bpta)]⋅solve, was obtained by the solvothermal reaction of tpt, H4bpta and Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O in DMF and characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction . In 2, the Cd(II) ions are seven coordinated by three nitrogen atoms from three tpt ligands, and four oxygen atoms from two carboxylate groups of two different H2bpta2- ligands with chelating mode. The Cd–O bond lengths vary from 2.365(17) to 2.422(10)Å, and the Cd–N bond lengths range from 2.393(9) to 2.462(15)Å. Ignoring the connectivity of H2bpta2−, the subnet formed by Cd(II) ions and tpt ligands shows 3-coordinated uniform self-penetrating twt network topology . However, with the Cd(II) ions interconnected by H2bpta2–, the whorl of separated helix chains assembled with Cd(II) ions and tpt ligands was supported and reinforced by the coordination of H2bpta2− with Cd(II) (a) to form a single triple-helix chain. The topology of 2 can be explained as follows. The Cd(II) ions could be simplified as five connected nodes meanwhile the tpt ligands can be considered as three connected nodes. As a result, the original twt topology was modified into a non-reported 3,5-coordinated chiral topology (c) with vertex symbol (4.72)(43.62.74.8) . A void space analysis indicates that the solvent accessible void in the structure of 2 reaches 52.5% (2070.4Å3 out of the 3946.2Å3 unit cell volume).

other properties: Cd–O bond lengths vary from 2.365(17) to 2.422(10)Å
Cd–N bond lengths range from 2.393(9) to 2.462(15)Å
solvent accessible void in the structure of 2 reaches 52.5% (2070.4Å3 out of the 3946.2Å3 unit cell volume)

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0025" view="all">To study the thermal stability of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, thermalgravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed. Fresh sample of both <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> show obvious lose of weight upon the rising of temperature, which corresponds to the departure of solvent molecules from the porous framework. And a platform indicating the lost of all solvent molecules was observed before the starting of framework decomposition over 250<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. After exchanging high boiling-point solvents in the pores and channels of as-synthesized MOFs with low boiling-point solvents followed by evacuation at elevated temperatures, the TG traces of activated samples keeps steady till the decomposition temperature. The stability of frameworks was also indicated by thermodiffractometry as there was no significant exothermic peak before 250<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: To study the thermal stability of complexes 1 and 2, thermalgravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed. Fresh sample of both 1 and 2 show obvious lose of weight upon the rising of temperature, which corresponds to the departure of solvent molecules from the porous framework. And a platform indicating the lost of all solvent molecules was observed before the starting of framework decomposition over 250°C. After exchanging high boiling-point solvents in the pores and channels of as-synthesized MOFs with low boiling-point solvents followed by evacuation at elevated temperatures, the TG traces of activated samples keeps steady till the decomposition temperature. The stability of frameworks was also indicated by thermodiffractometry as there was no significant exothermic peak before 250°C.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0030" view="all">Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) studies indicated that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> occurred significant peak broadening after the vacuum activation of sample and the only obvious peak show a movement toward high angle field. These indicated a decrease of cell volume and much smaller crystalline domains which might be attributed to the shrink of framework caused by internal tension and evaporation of solvent. It is interesting that the new PXRD pattern can be reverted to that of the pristine sample by soaking the activated sample in H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O. These results are indicative of a breathing phenomenon during the activate process . In the case of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the pattern recorded after vacuum activation show much smaller crystalline domains comparing with well crystallized sample due to the sensitivity of activated sample to oxygen and moisture in the air.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) studies indicated that 1 occurred significant peak broadening after the vacuum activation of sample and the only obvious peak show a movement toward high angle field. These indicated a decrease of cell volume and much smaller crystalline domains which might be attributed to the shrink of framework caused by internal tension and evaporation of solvent. It is interesting that the new PXRD pattern can be reverted to that of the pristine sample by soaking the activated sample in H2O. These results are indicative of a breathing phenomenon during the activate process . In the case of 2, the pattern recorded after vacuum activation show much smaller crystalline domains comparing with well crystallized sample due to the sensitivity of activated sample to oxygen and moisture in the air.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0035" view="all">Preliminary gas sorption studies were performed with activated <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>). The N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> sorption isotherm of both <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> shows type I gas sorption behavior indicative of microporous structure. The vacuum-dried sample of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibited a Langmuir surface area of 393<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>m<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> (a S<ce:inf loc="post">A</ce:inf>BET of 299<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>m<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>g<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>) whereas the sample of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> gave a Langmuir surface area of 442<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>m<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>g<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> (a S<ce:inf loc="post">A</ce:inf>BET of 336 m<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>g<ce:sup loc="post">-1</ce:sup>). Hydrogen adsorption isotherms measured at 77<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K reveal an uptake of 65<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> at 800<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmHg for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. Similarly, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> afford an uptake of 70<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>g<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> at 800<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmHg. Both uptakes of N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> are relatively low considering the highly porous nature of these MOFs materials, presumably because of the blockage of the cavity and channel in the activated sample accordingly to the change of structure during the activation process. Better results were expected by the enhancement of porosity using proper activating method .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Preliminary gas sorption studies were performed with activated 1 and 2 (
). The N2 sorption isotherm of both 1 and 2 shows type I gas sorption behavior indicative of microporous structure. The vacuum-dried sample of 1 exhibited a Langmuir surface area of 393m2
g−1 (a SABET of 299m2
g−1) whereas the sample of 2 gave a Langmuir surface area of 442m2
g−1 (a SABET of 336 m2g-1). Hydrogen adsorption isotherms measured at 77K reveal an uptake of 65cm3
g−1 at 800mmHg for 1. Similarly, 2 afford an uptake of 70cm3
g−1 at 800mmHg. Both uptakes of N2 and H2 are relatively low considering the highly porous nature of these MOFs materials, presumably because of the blockage of the cavity and channel in the activated sample accordingly to the change of structure during the activation process. Better results were expected by the enhancement of porosity using proper activating method .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0040" view="all">In summary, two porous MOFs were successfully constructed by Ni(II)/Cd(II), Tpt and H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>bpta. Compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> display high solvent-accessible volumes, and their gas adsorption properties were investigated. The successful preparation of these coordination polymers provides a potential sense into the rational design and synthesis of metal–organic frameworks with interesting structures and properties in the future.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In summary, two porous MOFs were successfully constructed by Ni(II)/Cd(II), Tpt and H4bpta. Compounds 1 and 2 display high solvent-accessible volumes, and their gas adsorption properties were investigated. The successful preparation of these coordination polymers provides a potential sense into the rational design and synthesis of metal–organic frameworks with interesting structures and properties in the future.

</ce:para><ce:section-title>Supplementary material</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0055" view="all">X-ray crystallographic data for complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> in CIF format, general characterizations (PXRD, IR and TGA), crystallographic data and additional structure figures. Supplementary data to this article can be found online at <ce:inter-ref xlink:href="doi:10.1016/j.inoche.2011.03.047" xlink:type="simple">doi:10.1016/j.inoche.2011.03.047</ce:inter-ref>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Supplementary data




Supplementary material 1







Supplementary material 2







Supplementary material 3





Supplementary material
X-ray crystallographic data for complexes 1 and 2 in CIF format, general characterizations (PXRD, IR and TGA), crystallographic data and additional structure figures. Supplementary data to this article can be found online at doi:10.1016/j.inoche.2011.03.047.

elements.content: <ce:simple-para id="sp0050" view="all">Synthesis of [Ni(tpt)<ce:inf loc="post">2/3</ce:inf>(bpta)<ce:inf loc="post">1/4</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(OH)]⋅solve (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>). Ni(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>⋅<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (58.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) was added to 18<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL 1:1 (v/v) mixture of methanol and water containing tpt (15.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.05<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) and H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>bpta (16.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg,0.05<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) under stirring. The green suspension was then sealed in a 25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel and heated to 140 °C for 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>days. Upon cooling to room temperature, octahedron green crystals were obtained (ca. 40<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 50% yield based on Ni). Crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were collected, washed with methanol, and dried in air. Anal. found: C, 42.24; H, 4.97; N, 8.66%.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text: Synthesis of [Ni(tpt)2/3(bpta)1/4(H2O)2(OH)]⋅solve (1). Ni(NO3)2⋅6H2O (58.2mg, 0.2mmol) was added to 18mL 1:1 (v/v) mixture of methanol and water containing tpt (15.5mg, 0.05mmol) and H4bpta (16.5mg,0.05mmol) under stirring. The green suspension was then sealed in a 25mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel and heated to 140 °C for 2days. Upon cooling to room temperature, octahedron green crystals were obtained (ca. 40mg, 50% yield based on Ni). Crystals of 1 were collected, washed with methanol, and dried in air. Anal. found: C, 42.24; H, 4.97; N, 8.66%.

elements.content:
<ce:simple-para id="sp0055" view="all">X-ray single crystal diffraction data for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was collected on a Rigaku Saturn 70 diffractometer at 293(2) K with Mo Kα radiation (λ<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) by ω scan mode, and diffraction data for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> was collected on a Rigaku SCX-mini diffractometer at 293(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>K with Mo Kα radiation (λ<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) by ω scan mode. The program SAINT was used for integration of the diffraction profiles. All the structures were solved by direct methods using the SHELXS program of the SHELXTL package and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods with SHELXL (semiempirical absorption corrections were applied using SADABS program). Metal atoms in each complex were located from the E-maps. Other non-hydrogen atoms in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were located in successive difference Fourier syntheses and refined with anisotropic thermal parameters on <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>. The location of hydrogen atoms of coordinated water and hydroxy were not able to be assigend. Part of the non-hydrogen atoms in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were fixed at the theoretical sites and refined with isotropic thermal parameters together with the hydrogen atoms ride on. The hydrogen atoms of the ligands were generated theoretically onto the specific atoms and refined isotropically with fixed thermal factors. Free solvent molecules in both <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were highly disordered, and attempts to locate and refine the solvent peaks were unsuccessful. The diffuse electron densities resulting from the these residual solvent molecules were removed from the data set using the SQUEEZE routine of PLATON and refined further using the data generated. The contents of the solvent region are not represented in the unit cell contents in crystal data. Attempts to determine the final formula of such compounds from the SQUEEZE results combined with elemental analysis and TGA data were also unsuccessful because of the volatility of solvents; therefore, an accurate data set could not be obtained. The contents of the solvent region are not represented in the unit cell contents in crystal data. Crystal data for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>: C<ce:inf loc="post">32</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">19</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>Ni<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>, <ce:italic>M<ce:inf loc="post">r</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>792.93, cubic, <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>-43<ce:italic>c</ce:italic> (No.219), <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>42.763(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>Å, <ce:italic>V</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>78200(16) Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>, <ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>48, d<ce:inf loc="post">calcd</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0.808<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>3</ce:sup>, <ce:italic>R</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">int</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0.11, final <ce:italic>R</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0.0395 <ce:italic>(I<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>><ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>2sigma(I))</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>w</ce:italic>R<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0.0935 (all data), GOF<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0.995. CCDC No.: 779828.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
X-ray single crystal diffraction data for 1 was collected on a Rigaku Saturn 70 diffractometer at 293(2) K with Mo Kα radiation (λ=0.71073Å) by ω scan mode, and diffraction data for 2 was collected on a Rigaku SCX-mini diffractometer at 293(2)K with Mo Kα radiation (λ=0.71073Å) by ω scan mode. The program SAINT was used for integration of the diffraction profiles. All the structures were solved by direct methods using the SHELXS program of the SHELXTL package and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods with SHELXL (semiempirical absorption corrections were applied using SADABS program). Metal atoms in each complex were located from the E-maps. Other non-hydrogen atoms in 1 were located in successive difference Fourier syntheses and refined with anisotropic thermal parameters on F
2. The location of hydrogen atoms of coordinated water and hydroxy were not able to be assigend. Part of the non-hydrogen atoms in 2 were fixed at the theoretical sites and refined with isotropic thermal parameters together with the hydrogen atoms ride on. The hydrogen atoms of the ligands were generated theoretically onto the specific atoms and refined isotropically with fixed thermal factors. Free solvent molecules in both 1 and 2 were highly disordered, and attempts to locate and refine the solvent peaks were unsuccessful. The diffuse electron densities resulting from the these residual solvent molecules were removed from the data set using the SQUEEZE routine of PLATON and refined further using the data generated. The contents of the solvent region are not represented in the unit cell contents in crystal data. Attempts to determine the final formula of such compounds from the SQUEEZE results combined with elemental analysis and TGA data were also unsuccessful because of the volatility of solvents; therefore, an accurate data set could not be obtained. The contents of the solvent region are not represented in the unit cell contents in crystal data. Crystal data for 1: C32H19N8Ni2O10, Mr

=792.93, cubic, F-43c (No.219), a
=42.763(5)Å, V
=78200(16) Å3, Z
=48, dcalcd
=0.808gcm−3, R
int
=0.11, final R
1
=0.0395 (I>2sigma(I)), wR2
=0.0935 (all data), GOF=0.995. CCDC No.: 779828.

elements.content: <ce:simple-para id="sp0060" view="all">Synthesis of [Cd(tpt)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>bpta)] ⋅<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>solve (2). Cd(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>⋅4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (30.8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), tpt (15.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.05<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) and H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>bpta (16.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg,0.05<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) was mixed in 14<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL DMF in a vial. The vial was sealed and allowed to stand at 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 24<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h. As the reaction progresses, light yellow rod shape crystal formed. Homogeneous crystals of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were collected, washed with DMF, and dried in air (yield: 35<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg). Anal. found: C, 50.83; H, 4.19; N, 13.52%.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text: Synthesis of [Cd(tpt)(H2bpta)] ⋅solve (2). Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O (30.8mg, 0.1mmol), tpt (15.5mg, 0.05mmol) and H4bpta (16.5mg,0.05mmol) was mixed in 14mL DMF in a vial. The vial was sealed and allowed to stand at 100°C for 24h. As the reaction progresses, light yellow rod shape crystal formed. Homogeneous crystals of 2 were collected, washed with DMF, and dried in air (yield: 35mg). Anal. found: C, 50.83; H, 4.19; N, 13.52%.

elements.content:

metadata.title: Synthesis, structure and properties of microporous metal–organic frameworks constructed from Ni(II)/Cd(II), Tpt and H4bpta
